data.career_path: 1912: Commissioned as a second lieutenant in the French Army. World War I: Served with distinction and was wounded in battle. Interwar Period: Advocated for armored warfare and wrote influential military treatises. 1940: Became a Brigadier General and later, a Colonel, but openly opposed the French armistice with Nazi Germany and fled to England to continue the fight. 1940-1944: Led the Free French Forces and became a prominent figure in the French Resistance. 1944: Returned to France after the liberation and played a significant role in the government. 1946-1953: Served in various government positions, including Prime Minister. 1958: Called to lead the French government amidst a political crisis and drafted a new constitution for the Fifth Republic. 1959-1969: Served as the first President of the Fifth Republic. 1969: Retired from politics after a referendum defeat but remained an influential public figure until his death on November 9, 1970.

data.name: Indira Gandhi
data.description: Indira Gandhi was an influential Indian politician and the first woman Prime Minister of India. Born on November 19, 1917, in Allahabad, India, she was the daughter of Jawaharlal Nehru, the first Prime Minister of independent India. Indira Gandhi played a significant role in Indian politics, serving as Prime Minister from 1966 to 1977 and again from 1980 until her assassination in 1984. She was known for her strong leadership, political acumen, and determination in pursuing various socio-economic policies. During her tenure, she implemented the Green Revolution and the nationalization of banks, among other initiatives. However, her leadership also faced challenges, including the imposition of the state of emergency from 1975 to 1977. Despite her controversial decisions, she remains a prominent figure in Indian history and a symbol of women's empowerment in politics.
data.education: Educated at Modern School, Delhi. Studied at Visva-Bharati University in Santiniketan, founded by Rabindranath Tagore. Completed her education at the University of Oxford, UK.
data.career_path: 1940s: Active in the Indian National Congress and the freedom movement against British colonial rule. 1947: India gained independence, and her father, Jawaharlal Nehru, became the first Prime Minister. 1966: After the death of Prime Minister Lal Bahadur Shastri, Indira Gandhi was elected as the leader of the Indian National Congress and became the Prime Minister of India. 1971: Led India to victory in the Indo-Pakistani War, resulting in the creation of Bangladesh. 1975: Declared a state of emergency, leading to the suspension of civil liberties and opposition suppression.

data.name: Ho Chi Minh
data.description: Ho Chi Minh, born on May 19, 1890, in Nghe An province, Vietnam (then part of French Indochina), was a Vietnamese revolutionary leader and the founding father of the Democratic Republic of Vietnam, known as North Vietnam. He played a crucial role in the fight for Vietnamese independence from French colonial rule and later, during the Vietnam War, led the struggle against American involvement in Vietnam. Ho Chi Minh was a prominent figure in the Communist movement and served as the President (1945-1969) and founding member of the Vietnamese Communist Party. He is widely revered in Vietnam for his leadership and dedication to the cause of Vietnamese independence and socialism.
data.education: Ho Chi Minh began his formal education at a local school in his hometown of Kim Lien in Nghe An Province, Vietnam. In 1911, he moved to Hue and enrolled in the National Academy, where he studied under the name Nguyen Tat Thanh. In 1913, Ho Chi Minh traveled to France to pursue further studies. He attended various schools and universities in Paris, including the School of Oriental Studies, and gained exposure to revolutionary ideas and anti-colonial movements.
data.career_path: In the early 1920s, Ho Chi Minh traveled to different countries, including the Soviet Union, where he was influenced by Marxist-Leninist ideology and the principles of communism. In 1925, he became a founding member of the French Communist Party. Ho Chi Minh played a prominent role in organizing Vietnamese revolutionary movements and co-founded the Indochinese Communist Party (ICP) in 1930, which later became the Vietnamese Communist Party. Throughout the 1940s and 1950s, he led the Viet Minh, a communist-led resistance organization that fought against Japanese occupation during World War II and against French colonial forces for Vietnam's independence. On September 2, 1945, Ho Chi Minh declared the independence of the Democratic Republic of Vietnam. During the Vietnam War, he continued to lead North Vietnam's resistance against the United States and South Vietnam. Ho Chi Minh passed away on September 2, 1969, but his legacy as a revolutionary leader and symbol of Vietnamese nationalism and communism continues to be celebrated in Vietnam and beyond.

data.name: Emmanuel Macron

Born on December 21, 1977, in Amiens, France, he is a centrist leader and the founder of the political party "En Marche!" (On the Move!). Macron rose to prominence with his election to the presidency on May 7, 2017, at the age of 39, making him the youngest president in French history. He is known for his pro-European stance, advocating for economic reforms, and promoting a more inclusive and modern France

Deputy Secretary-General: In 2012, Macron returned to the public sector and became the Deputy Secretary-General at the Élysée Palace, working under President François Hollande. Minister of Economy, Industry and Digital Affairs: From 2014 to 2016, he served as the Minister of Economy, Industry, and Digital Affairs in the French government, where he implemented significant economic reforms and advocated for pro-business policies. President of France: In 2017, Emmanuel Macron won the French presidential election as an independent candidate, defeating Marine Le Pen of the National Front. He assumed office as the President of France on May 14, 2017, and has since been leading the nation through various domestic and international challenges.

data.name: Jacinda Ardern
data.description: Jacinda Ardern is a New Zealand politician who currently serves as the Prime Minister of New Zealand. Born on July 26, 1980, in Hamilton, New Zealand, she is a member of the New Zealand Labour Party. Ardern's leadership gained global attention for her compassionate and progressive policies. She became the youngest-ever leader of the Labour Party in 2017 and led the party to victory in the general election later that year. Known for her strong stance on issues like climate change and social welfare, Ardern's inclusive and empathetic approach has earned her widespread admiration.
data.education: Morrinsville College: Ardern attended Morrinsville College in New Zealand. University of Waikato: She pursued her higher education at the University of Waikato, where she graduated with a Bachelor of Communication Studies in Politics and Public Relations in 2001.
data.career_path: Early Career: Ardern began her political journey as a researcher in the office of Prime Minister Helen Clark. She then worked for the British Home Office in London. President of the International Union of Socialist Youth: From 2008 to 2009, she served as the President of the International Union of Socialist Youth, advocating for youth issues on an international level. Member of Parliament: In 2008, Ardern was elected as a Member of Parliament (MP) for the Labour Party, representing the electorate of Auckland Central. Labour Party Spokesperson: Over the years, she held various roles within the Labour Party, including spokesperson for Youth Affairs, Arts, and Children. Leader of the Labour Party: In 2017, Ardern was elected as the Leader of the New Zealand Labour Party, taking over just weeks before the general election. Prime Minister of New Zealand: Following the general election on September 23, 2017, Jacinda Ardern led the Labour Party to victory, forming a coalition government, and on October 26, 2017, she was sworn in as the 40th Prime Minister of New Zealand. She was re-elected in 2020 for a second term.

data.name: Shinzo Abe
data.description: Born on September 21, 1954, in Tokyo, Japan, he is a member of the Liberal Democratic Party (LDP). Abe is known for his conservative views and strong leadership. He comes from a prominent political family; his grandfather, Nobusuke Kishi, was a former Prime Minister of Japan. Shinzo Abe is recognized for his economic policies, referred to as "Abenomics," which aimed to revitalize Japan's economy. Throughout his political career, he played a significant role in shaping Japan's foreign relations and security policies.

Chief Cabinet Secretary: In 2005, he became the Chief Cabinet Secretary under Prime Minister Junichiro Koizumi's administration, where he was responsible for coordinating government policies and serving as the government's spokesperson. First Term as Prime Minister: Shinzo Abe was elected as the Prime Minister of Japan on September 26, 2006. However, due to health issues, he resigned from the position on September 12, 2007, after serving for one year. Leader of the Opposition: Following his resignation, he continued to be an influential figure in Japanese politics and served as the Leader of the Opposition in the House of Representatives. Second Term as Prime Minister: Abe was re-elected as the Prime Minister on December 26, 2012. During his second term, he focused on economic reforms, strengthening Japan's defense capabilities, and advancing the country's role in international affairs. He resigned on September 16, 2020, citing health reasons, after serving as Prime Minister for nearly eight years, making him the longest-serving Prime Minister in Japan's history.

Prime Minister of the United Kingdom (2019-present): After winning the leadership of the Conservative Party in July 2019, Boris Johnson succeeded Theresa May as Prime Minister of the United Kingdom. data.name: Recep Tayyip Erdoğan
data.description: Recep Tayyip Erdoğan is a Turkish politician who has been a prominent figure in Turkish politics for several decades. He served as the President of Turkey, assuming office on August 28, 2014. President of Turkey (2014-present): After serving as Prime Minister, Recep Tayyip Erdoğan became the 12th President of Turkey on August 28, 2014. He won the presidential election in August 2014 and was re-elected in June 2018.

data.name: Justin Trudeau
data.description: Justin Trudeau is a Canadian politician and the 23rd Prime Minister of Canada, serving in this position since November 4, 2015. Born on December 25, 1971, in Ottawa, Ontario, he is the eldest son of former Canadian Prime Minister Pierre Trudeau and Margaret Trudeau. Trudeau is a member of the Liberal Party of Canada and is known for his progressive and inclusive approach to governance. Trudeau's leadership style and policies have both garnered praise and faced criticism, making him a significant and polarizing figure in Canadian politics
data.education: McGill University (1994-1998): Justin Trudeau attended McGill University in Montreal, Quebec, where he pursued a Bachelor of Arts degree in Literature, graduating in 1994. Prime Minister of Canada (2015-present): Following the Liberal Party's victory in the 2015 election, Justin Trudeau became the Prime Minister of Canada on November 4, 2015. data.name: Alberto Fernández

data.name: Henry Ford

data.education: 1879: Henry Ford attended a one-room schoolhouse in Dearborn, Michigan. 1888: He completed the basic education and began working as an apprentice machinist.
data.career_path: 1891: Henry Ford became an engineer for the Edison Illuminating Company in Detroit. 1896: He built his first gasoline-powered vehicle, the Quadricycle. 1903: Ford co-founded the Ford Motor Company, and the first Model A was produced. 1908: The Model T was introduced, becoming immensely popular due to its affordability and practicality. 1913: Ford implemented the assembly line production method, dramatically increasing the efficiency of automobile manufacturing. 1914: He increased worker wages significantly with the introduction of the $5-a-day wage, setting a new standard for industrial pay. 1919: Henry Ford bought out his shareholders to become the sole owner of the Ford Motor Company. 1927: The last Model T was produced, and the Model A was introduced. 1943: Henry Ford's grandson, Henry Ford II, took over the company's management.

data.name: John D. Rockefeller
data.description: John D. Rockefeller was an American businessman and industrialist who rose to prominence in the late 19th and early 20th centuries. He is widely regarded as one of the most successful and influential figures in the history of the oil industry. Rockefeller co-founded the Standard Oil Company, which became the dominant force in the oil refining and marketing business, ultimately making him one of the wealthiest individuals of his time.
data.education: 1855: At the age of 16, John D. Rockefeller enrolled in a commercial college, Folsom's Commercial College, in Cleveland, Ohio
data.career_path: 1859: Rockefeller formed a partnership with Maurice B. Clark, investing in a commission business dealing with hay, grain, meats, and other goods. 1863: He established a small oil refinery in Cleveland, Ohio, marking the beginning of his ventures in the oil industry. 1870: Rockefeller co-founded the Standard Oil Company, which rapidly grew and acquired numerous refineries, pipelines, and marketing outlets, dominating the oil market. 1882: Standard Oil Trust was formed, consolidating the various companies under one entity and further enhancing Rockefeller's control over the industry. 1897: Amid growing public and legal scrutiny, the Standard Oil Trust was dissolved, and its component companies were reorganized into separate entities, including Standard Oil of New Jersey (Exxon), Standard Oil of New York (Mobil), and others. Late 19th to early 20th century: Rockefeller focused on philanthropy and established several charitable foundations, most notably the Rockefeller Foundation, which funded various projects in education, medicine, and scientific research.

data.name: Andrew Carnegie
data.description: Andrew Carnegie was a Scottish-American industrialist and philanthropist who played a significant role in the expansion of the American steel industry during the late 19th century. Born in Scotland, Carnegie immigrated to the United States with his family in 1848, and through hard work and strategic business decisions, he amassed immense wealth, becoming one of the richest individuals in history. Carnegie is best known for founding the Carnegie Steel Company, which eventually became a major component of the United States Steel Corporation. Despite his immense fortune, he dedicated the latter part of his life to philanthropy, funding various educational, cultural, and scientific institutions.
data.education: 1848: Andrew Carnegie's family immigrated to the United States, settling in Allegheny, Pennsylvania. 1851: Carnegie began attending school in Allegheny at the age of 15.
data.career_path: 1853: At the age of 18, Carnegie started working as a bobbin boy in a cotton factory, earning $1.20 per week. 1855: He became a telegraph messenger boy for the Pennsylvania Railroad Company, where he gained valuable knowledge of the railroad and telegraph industries. 1859: Carnegie was promoted to become the personal telegrapher and secretary to the superintendent of the Pittsburgh division of the Pennsylvania Railroad. 1865: After the Civil War, Carnegie left the railroad industry to focus on investments and ventures in the iron and steel industry. 1870s: Carnegie made strategic investments in various steel-related businesses, gradually expanding his influence in the industry. 1873: He co-founded the Keystone Bridge Company, which specialized in building iron bridges. 1875: Carnegie founded the Carnegie Steel Company, utilizing vertical integration and innovative production methods to become one of the leading steel manufacturers in the world. 1901: Carnegie sold his steel company to J.P. Morgan, becoming part of the newly formed United States Steel Corporation, the first billion-dollar corporation in the world. Late 19th to early 20th century: After his retirement from the steel industry, Carnegie focused on philanthropy, donating a vast portion of his wealth to establish libraries, schools, universities, and cultural institutions, leaving a lasting legacy in the realm of education and culture.

data.name: Walt Disney
data.description: Walt Disney was an American filmmaker, entrepreneur, and visionary who co-founded The Walt Disney Company, one of the world's most renowned entertainment conglomerates. Born in 1901 in Chicago, Illinois, Disney showed a keen interest in art and animation from a young age. He is best known for creating iconic characters such as Mickey Mouse and for producing the world's first full-length animated feature film, "Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs." Disney's boundless imagination and innovative animation techniques revolutionized the entertainment industry, making him a pioneer in animation and a beloved figure in the hearts of millions worldwide.
data.education: 1909: Walt Disney's family moved to Kansas City, Missouri, where he attended the Benton Grammar School. 1911: He began taking drawing classes at the Kansas City Art Institute during his spare time. 1917: At the age of 16, Disney dropped out of high school to join the American Ambulance Corps during World War I but was rejected for being underage
data.career_path: 1919: After returning from World War I, Disney started his career as a commercial artist, creating advertisements and cartoons for local businesses in Kansas City. 1920: He co-founded the Kansas City Film Ad Company, producing animated commercials. 1923: Disney moved to Hollywood, California, and founded the Disney Brothers Studio with his brother Roy O. Disney. Later, the company was rebranded as The Walt Disney Company. 1928: Mickey Mouse, Disney's most iconic creation, made his debut in the animated short film "Steamboat Willie." 1937: "Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs" premiered, marking the first full-length animated feature film and a major milestone in the animation industry. 1955: Disneyland, the world's first modern theme park, opened in Anaheim, California. 1966: Walt Disney passed away, but his legacy continued to thrive through the company he founded, which expanded to include television networks, amusement parks, and a vast array of beloved films and characters.

data.name: Warren Buffett
data.description: Warren Buffett, often referred to as the "Oracle of Omaha," is an American investor, business tycoon, and philanthropist. Born in 1930 in Omaha, Nebraska, Buffett demonstrated an early interest in business and investing. He is the chairman and CEO of Berkshire Hathaway, a multinational conglomerate holding company. Buffett is widely regarded as one of the most successful investors in history, known for his value investing approach and long-term perspective on stock investments. He is also known for his philanthropic efforts, notably pledging to give away the majority of his wealth through The Giving Pledge, an initiative he co-founded with Bill and Melinda Gates to encourage wealthy individuals to commit to charitable giving.
data.education: 1945: Warren Buffett graduated from Woodrow Wilson High School in Washington, D.C. 1947: He enrolled at the Wharton School of the University of Pennsylvania but transferred to the University of Nebraska-Lincoln after two years. 1950: Buffett graduated with a Bachelor of Science degree in Business Administration from the University of Nebraska-Lincoln. 1951: He attended the Columbia Business School for his Master of Science degree in Economics, studying under Benjamin Graham, a renowned value investor and author of "The Intelligent Investor."
data.career_path: 1951: After completing his studies at Columbia, Buffett worked briefly as a securities analyst at Graham-Newman Corp., a New York investment firm founded by Benjamin Graham. 1956: Buffett started his own investment partnership, Buffett Associates, Ltd., with seven limited partners, including family and friends. 1962: He began buying shares of Berkshire Hathaway, a struggling textile company, and eventually gained control of the company. 1970s-1980s: Under Buffett's leadership, Berkshire Hathaway shifted its focus to acquiring various businesses and investments, becoming a diversified conglomerate. 1985: Buffett acquired a significant stake in Coca-Cola, making it one of Berkshire Hathaway's most successful investments. 2006: Buffett pledged to donate the bulk of his wealth to philanthropic causes, primarily through The Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation and other charitable organizations. Present: Warren Buffett continues to lead Berkshire Hathaway and remains an influential figure in the financial world, with his annual letters to shareholders and investment decisions closely followed by investors and analysts worldwide.

data.name: Thomas J. Watson
data.description: Thomas J. Watson was an American entrepreneur and businessman who is best known for his significant contributions to the computing industry. He was born on February 17, 1874, in Campbell, New York, and passed away on June 19, 1956. Watson is widely recognized as the founder of IBM (International Business Machines Corporation), which became one of the world's largest and most influential technology companies. Under his leadership, IBM played a pivotal role in the development of early computing systems and helped shape the modern computer industry. Watson's relentless drive, innovative thinking, and strong leadership skills have left a lasting impact on the world of technology and business.
data.education: Attended public schools in Campbell and Painted Post, New York. 1891: Enrolled at the Elmira Free Academy in Elmira, New York. Left the Elmira Free Academy before graduating to pursue employment opportunities.

Watson served as its president. 1952: Stepped down as President but remained Chairman of the Board at IBM until his retirement in 1956, shortly before his passing.

data.name: Steve Jobs
data.description: Steve Jobs was an American entrepreneur, visionary, and co-founder of Apple Inc. He was born on February 24, 1955, in San Francisco, California, and passed away on October 5, 2011. Jobs is widely regarded as one of the pioneers of the personal computer revolution and the consumer electronics industry. Along with his friend Steve Wozniak, he co-founded Apple in 1976 in his family's garage. Under his leadership, Apple introduced game-changing products like the Macintosh computer, iPod, iPhone, and iPad, which revolutionized the way people interact with technology. Known for his uncompromising attention to design, user experience, and innovation, Jobs reshaped multiple industries and left a lasting legacy on the world of technology and entrepreneurship.
data.education: 1972: Graduated from Homestead High School in Cupertino, California. Enrolled at Reed College in Portland, Oregon, but dropped out after just one semester. 1974: Attended some creative classes at Reed College, including a calligraphy course, which later influenced Apple's design aesthetics.
data.career_path: 1974: After dropping out of college, Jobs returned to California and started attending meetings of the Homebrew Computer Club, where he met Steve Wozniak. 1976: Co-founded Apple Computer Inc. (later renamed Apple Inc.) with Steve Wozniak and Ronald Wayne. Apple's first product, the Apple I, was released the same year. 1983: Launched the Apple Lisa, one of the first computers with a graphical user interface. 1984: Introduced the Macintosh computer with a now-iconic Super Bowl commercial. 1985: Left Apple following a power struggle with the board of directors and started NeXT Inc., a computer company focused on higher education and business markets. 1986: Acquired Pixar Animation Studios from George Lucas and served as its CEO. 1996: Apple acquired NeXT, and Jobs returned to Apple as an advisor. 1997: Became the interim CEO of Apple, eventually dropping the "interim" title and assuming full control. 2001: Unveiled the iPod, which transformed the music industry and marked the beginning of Apple's consumer electronics dominance. 2007: Introduced the iPhone, revolutionizing the smartphone industry and solidifying Apple's position as a global technology leader. 2010: Launched the iPad, creating a new market for tablet computers and further cementing Apple's influence on modern technology.

data.name: Ray Kroc
data.description: Ray Kroc was an American entrepreneur and the mastermind behind the global success of McDonald's, one of the world's largest and most iconic fast-food chains. He was born on October 5, 1902, in Oak Park, Illinois, and passed away on January 14, 1984. Kroc's involvement with McDonald's began in 1954 when he was a struggling milkshake machine salesperson. Impressed by the efficiency and popularity of the original McDonald's restaurant, which was owned by Richard and Maurice McDonald in San Bernardino, California, Kroc saw the potential for its rapid expansion. He convinced the McDonald brothers to let him franchise the brand and built the franchise model that transformed McDonald's into a global fast-food empire. Under his leadership, McDonald's expanded rapidly, emphasizing uniformity, consistency, and fast service. Today, McDonald's stands as a testament to Kroc's pioneering vision and business acumen.
data.education: 1917: Graduated from Oak Park and River Forest High School in Oak Park, Illinois.
data.career_path: 1922: Enlisted in the Red Cross ambulance service as an ambulance driver during World War I. After the war, worked a variety of jobs, including as a jazz musician and a paper cup salesman. 1930s-1940s: Operated a number of unsuccessful business ventures, including a music company and a chain of drive-in restaurants called the "Lily-Tulip Cup" franchise. 1954: At the age of 52, Ray Kroc came across the McDonald's restaurant in San Bernardino, California, and was inspired by its innovative "Speedee Service System." 1955: Formed a partnership with Richard and Maurice McDonald, purchasing the rights to franchise McDonald's and opening the first franchised McDonald's restaurant in Des Plaines, Illinois. 1961: Bought out the McDonald brothers' share of the company for $2.7 million, gaining full control of the company's future. 1965: McDonald's Corporation went public, and Kroc became the company's first CEO. 1974: Stepped down as CEO but remained involved in the company's operations and served as the Chairman of the Board until his retirement in 1977. Throughout the 1970s and 1980s, McDonald's continued its global expansion, becoming a dominant force in the fast-food industry.

data.name: Akio Morita
data.description: Akio Morita was a prominent Japanese entrepreneur and co-founder of Sony Corporation, one of the world's leading electronics and entertainment companies. Born on January 26, 1921, in Nagoya, Japan, Morita played a vital role in revolutionizing the global electronics industry through Sony's innovative products and technologies.
data.education: 1944: Graduated from Osaka Imperial University (now Osaka University) with a degree in physics.
data.career_path: 1946: Co-founded Tokyo Tsushin Kogyo K.K. (Tokyo Telecommunications Engineering Corporation) with Masaru Ibuka, which later evolved into Sony Corporation. 1950: Sony introduced its first product, the tape recorder, under the brand name "Sony," derived from the Latin word "sonus" (sound) and the American slang "sonny." 1958: Morita and Ibuka took Sony Corporation public, expanding its operations globally. Throughout the 1960s and 1970s, Sony under Morita's leadership became a pioneer in various consumer electronics products, such as the Trinitron color television and the Walkman portable cassette player. 1994: Morita stepped down as the Chairman of Sony Corporation, but he remained as Honorary Chairman until his passing on October 3, 1999.

data.name: Henry J. Heinz
data.description: Henry John Heinz was a renowned American entrepreneur and the founder of the H.J. Heinz Company, a global food processing company famous for its ketchup and various food products. Born on October 11, 1844, in Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, Heinz was an innovative and visionary leader who revolutionized the food industry with his commitment to quality and wholesome products.
data.education: 1859: At the age of 15, Henry Heinz left school to work and contribute to his family's finances after his father's sudden death. Despite his limited formal education, he learned valuable business and marketing skills through his early experiences.
data.career_path: 1869: Henry Heinz founded his first company, "Heinz & Noble," which focused on selling grated horseradish. However, the venture faced challenges and eventually dissolved. 1876: Heinz established the "F & J Heinz Company" with his business partners, his brother Frederick Heinz, and his cousin Samuel V. Chamberlain. The company initially produced and sold horseradish, pickles, sauerkraut, and other preserved foods. 1876-1888: The company rapidly expanded, and Henry Heinz was instrumental in introducing innovative and hygienic packaging for his products, including the iconic glass bottles for ketchup. 1888: The company was renamed the H.J. Heinz Company, and it continued to grow and diversify its product line under Heinz's leadership. Throughout the late 19th and early 20th centuries, Heinz expanded the business internationally and introduced new products, making the company a household name. 1919: Henry Heinz passed away on May 14, leaving behind a successful legacy and a company that continued to thrive and innovate in the food industry

data.name: J. Paul Getty
data.description: Jean Paul Getty, commonly known as J. Paul Getty, was an American businessman and philanthropist, recognized as one of the wealthiest men in the world during his lifetime. Born on December 15, 1892, in Minneapolis, Minnesota, Getty made his fortune in the oil industry, establishing Getty Oil, which became a major player in the petroleum sector. He was known for his shrewd business acumen and his collection of art, which later formed the basis of the J. Paul Getty Museum.
data.education: 1914: J. Paul Getty graduated from the University of Oxford, England. He attended Magdalen College, where he studied political science and economics
data.career_path: 1916: Getty returned to the United States and took over his father's oil business in Tulsa, Oklahoma. He founded the Getty Oil Company, which played a significant role in his rise to immense wealth. 1930s-1940s: Getty made strategic investments and acquisitions in the oil industry, expanding his business empire both domestically and internationally. He acquired oil wells and refineries in various countries, including Saudi Arabia and the Middle East. 1950s-1960s: As Getty Oil's value increased, J. Paul Getty's personal wealth soared, and he became a prominent figure in the business world. 1976: J. Paul Getty passed away on June 6 in Surrey, England. His legacy as a successful businessman and art collector lived on, and his philanthropic endeavors, including the J. Paul Getty Trust, continue to have a lasting impact.

data.name: Sam Walton
data.description: Sam Walton was a renowned American entrepreneur and the founder of Walmart, one of the world's largest retail chains. Born on March 29, 1918, in Kingfisher, Oklahoma, Walton is considered a pioneer in the retail industry, revolutionizing the way Americans shop and changing the landscape of retail globally. He was known for his frugality, hands-on approach to business, and commitment to providing customers with quality products at affordable prices
data.education: 1940: Sam Walton graduated with a Bachelor of Science in Economics from the University of Missouri
data.career_path: 1945: After serving in the Army during World War II, Walton acquired a Ben Franklin variety store franchise in Newport, Arkansas. This marked the beginning of his career in the retail business. 1962: Walton opened the first Walmart Discount City store in Rogers, Arkansas. The store's success was built on Walton's innovative approach to retailing, offering a wide range of products at low prices. 1970s-1980s: Walmart expanded rapidly, opening stores across the United States and adopting distribution and inventory management techniques that set new standards in the retail industry. 1983: Walmart became a publicly traded company on the New York Stock Exchange, cementing its status as a major player in the retail sector. 1992: Sam Walton received the Presidential Medal of Freedom, recognizing his contributions to American business and society. 1992: Sam Walton passed away on April 5 in Little Rock, Arkansas, but his legacy as a visionary entrepreneur and his company's enduring success continue to impact the retail industry worldwide.

data.name: Howard Hughes
data.description: Howard Hughes was an American business magnate, investor, aviator, filmmaker, and philanthropist. Born on December 24, 1905, in Houston, Texas, Hughes was a multifaceted individual known for his diverse achievements in various industries. He gained fame as a pioneering aviator, setting several world records and founding Hughes Aircraft Company, a major aerospace and defense contractor. Hughes also ventured into filmmaking and produced critically acclaimed movies like "Hell's Angels" and "The Outlaw." Despite his successes, he became reclusive later in life and was plagued by health issues and controversy.
data.education: 1924: Howard Hughes attended the California Institute of Technology (Caltech) but left before completing his degree
data.career_path: 1932: Hughes founded the Hughes Aircraft Company, which initially focused on building and designing aircraft. The company played a crucial role in advancing aviation technology during World War II and beyond. 1938: Hughes set a record by flying around the world in 3 days, 19 hours, and 8 minutes, further solidifying his reputation as an accomplished aviator. 1948: Hughes ventured into the entertainment industry and produced "The Red River," a western film starring John Wayne. He later produced and directed movies like "Hell's Angels" and "The Outlaw," which received both praise and controversy for its provocative content. 1953: Hughes acquired RKO Pictures, a major Hollywood studio, and began exerting control over the film industry. 1966: Hughes was involved in a serious plane crash that exacerbated his reclusive behavior and health issues. In his later years, Hughes withdrew from public life, living in seclusion and dealing with obsessive-compulsive disorder. 1976: Howard Hughes passed away on April 5 in Houston, Texas, leaving behind a complex legacy as a brilliant and enigmatic figure who made significant contributions to various industries.

data.name: Ted Turner
data.description: Ted Turner is an American media mogul, entrepreneur, and philanthropist, widely recognized for his significant contributions to the television and media industry. Born on November 19, 1938, in Cincinnati, Ohio, Turner is the founder of CNN (Cable News Network), the world's first 24-hour cable news channel, revolutionizing the way news is delivered globally. He also established Turner Broadcasting System (TBS) and SuperStation WTBS, which later became TBS, the first independent TV station. A passionate yachtsman and environmentalist, Turner is known for his ambitious and innovative approach to business, as well as his substantial philanthropic efforts, including his involvement with the United Nations Foundation.
data.education: 1960: Ted Turner graduated with a Bachelor of Science degree in Classics from Brown University.
data.career_path: 1970: Turner purchased a failing UHF television station in Atlanta, Georgia, and rebranded it as WTCG, which became the first "SuperStation" and featured a mix of sports, movies, and syndicated programming. 1976: WTCG was renamed WTBS (Turner Broadcasting System), and it continued to grow in popularity as one of the pioneering cable networks. 1980: Turner launched CNN (Cable News Network), providing continuous news coverage and becoming a major player in the cable news industry. 1986: Turner expanded his media empire by acquiring MGM UA Entertainment Company, which included a vast library of classic films and television shows. 1996: Time Warner acquired Turner Broadcasting System, making Turner one of the company's largest shareholders. 2003: Ted Turner stepped down as Vice Chairman of Time Warner, but he continued to be involved in philanthropic activities and environmental causes, notably donating $1 billion to the United Nations.

data.name: Elon Musk
data.description: Elon Musk is a visionary entrepreneur and business magnate known for his significant contributions to the technology and space exploration industries. He was born on June 28, 1971, in Pretoria, South Africa. Musk co-founded and leads several high-profile companies, including SpaceX, Tesla Inc., Neuralink, and The Boring Company, with the aim of revolutionizing transportation, energy, and communication technologies. He is widely recognized for his ambitious goals, such as making human life multiplanetary by establishing a colony on Mars and accelerating the transition to sustainable energy through electric vehicles and solar energy solutions.
data.education: Queen's University, Kingston, Ontario, Canada (1990-1992): Musk attended Queen's University for undergraduate studies but transferred to the University of Pennsylvania after two years. University of Pennsylvania, Philadelphia, Pennsylvania, USA (1992-1995): At UPenn, Musk completed a Bachelor of Science degree in Economics from the Wharton School of Business and a Bachelor of Arts degree in Physics from the College of Arts and Sciences.
data.career_path: Zip2 Corporation (1996-1999): In 1996, Musk co-founded Zip2, a software company that provided business directories and maps for newspapers. Compaq acquired Zip2 in 1999, earning Musk a significant payout. X.com and PayPal (1999-2002): Musk founded X.com, an online payment company, which later became PayPal after a merger. In 2002, eBay acquired PayPal, resulting in Musk receiving a substantial share of the proceeds. SpaceX (2002-present): In 2002, Musk founded Space Exploration Technologies Corp. (SpaceX) with the goal of reducing space transportation costs and making space exploration more accessible. SpaceX has achieved numerous milestones, including launching reusable rockets and partnering with NASA for crewed missions to the International Space Station. Tesla Inc. (2004-present): Musk joined Tesla Motors (now Tesla Inc.) in 2004 as chairman and later became its CEO and product architect. Under his leadership, Tesla has become a leading manufacturer of electric vehicles, pushing the automotive industry towards sustainability. SolarCity (2006-2016): In 2006, Musk co-founded SolarCity, a solar energy services company aiming to promote clean and renewable energy solutions. Tesla acquired SolarCity in 2016, further integrating sustainable energy practices into its business. Neuralink (2016-present): Musk co-founded Neuralink in 2016, a neurotechnology company focused on developing brain-computer interface technologies to enable direct communication between the human brain and external devices. The Boring Company (2016-present): In 2016, Musk established The Boring Company, aiming to develop tunneling technology to reduce traffic congestion and revolutionize transportation in urban areas.

data.name: Mark Zuckerberg
data.description: Mark Zuckerberg is a renowned entrepreneur and computer programmer, best known as the co-founder and CEO of Facebook, the world's largest social media platform. Born on May 14, 1984, in White Plains, New York, USA, Zuckerberg's brilliance in programming was evident from a young age. He attended Harvard University, where he launched "The Facebook" in February 2004, initially as a platform for Harvard students to connect. The social network quickly expanded to other universities and eventually became known as Facebook. Zuckerberg's visionary leadership has led the company to tremendous success, with billions of active users worldwide. He played a crucial role in revolutionizing the way people communicate and share information globally, making Facebook a dominant force in the digital landscape. Besides his work at Facebook, Zuckerberg has been involved in various philanthropic efforts, including the Chan Zuckerberg Initiative, aimed at tackling global challenges through science and education.
data.education: Phillips Exeter Academy, New Hampshire, USA (1998-2002): Zuckerberg attended Phillips Exeter Academy, a prestigious preparatory school. Harvard University, Cambridge, Massachusetts, USA (2002-2004): Zuckerberg pursued a degree in Computer Science and Psychology at Harvard University before dropping out to focus on developing Facebook.
data.career_path: Facebook (2004-present): In February 2004, while still at Harvard, Zuckerberg co-founded "The Facebook," which later became Facebook Inc. The platform's rapid growth and popularity led to Zuckerberg dropping out of college to focus entirely on expanding and refining the social network. Under his leadership, Facebook expanded its services, acquired other tech companies, and became a dominant player in the tech industry. As CEO, Zuckerberg continues to shape Facebook's direction and lead the company through various challenges and opportunities.

data.name: Jack Ma
data.description: Jack Ma, whose real name is Ma Yun, is a prominent Chinese entrepreneur and the co-founder of Alibaba Group, one of the world's largest e-commerce and technology conglomerates. Born on September 10, 1964, in Hangzhou, China, Ma's early life was marked by challenges, including facing rejection from job applications and English proficiency tests. He graduated from Hangzhou Teacher's Institute (now known as Hangzhou Normal University) in 1988 with a Bachelor's degree in English. Later, he worked as an English teacher before venturing into the world of business. In 1999, Jack Ma co-founded Alibaba, an online marketplace aimed at connecting Chinese manufacturers with international buyers. Under his leadership, Alibaba expanded rapidly and diversified its services, including e-commerce platforms, online payment systems (Alipay), cloud computing, and digital entertainment. Jack Ma's entrepreneurial vision and leadership played a significant role in transforming Alibaba into a global tech giant, impacting the lives of millions of people and reshaping the landscape of digital commerce.
data.education: Hangzhou Teacher's Institute (now Hangzhou Normal University), Hangzhou, China (1984-1988): Jack Ma obtained a Bachelor's degree in English from Hangzhou Teacher's Institute.
data.career_path: English Teacher (1988-1995): After graduating, Ma worked as an English teacher at Hangzhou Dianzi University for several years. Internet Entrepreneur (1995-1999): In 1995, Ma discovered the internet during a trip to the United States and realized its potential for business. He co-founded China Yellow Pages, an online business directory. This venture led to the establishment of Alibaba in 1999, which became his most significant success in the business world. Alibaba Group (1999-present): Founded Alibaba in 1999 as an online marketplace to connect Chinese manufacturers with international buyers. Under his leadership as Chairman and later as Executive Chairman until 2019, Alibaba grew into a vast conglomerate, encompassing various businesses and services related to e-commerce, finance, cloud computing, and more. Jack Ma became a global business icon, known for his bold visions and contributions to the development of digital commerce in China and beyond.

data.name: Tim Cook
data.description: Tim Cook is the Chief Executive Officer (CEO) of Apple Inc., an American multinational technology company that designs, manufactures, and sells consumer electronics, software, and services. He is a highly influential and renowned figure in the tech industry. Cook is recognized for his strategic leadership, operational expertise, and commitment to innovation. Under his leadership, Apple has continued to thrive and expand its global footprint, delivering revolutionary products like the iPhone, iPad, and Apple Watch, and achieving significant financial success
data.education: Tim Cook graduated from Auburn University with a Bachelor of Science degree in Industrial Engineering in 1982
data.career_path: 1982: After completing his undergraduate degree, Cook joined IBM as a junior engineer, where he gained valuable experience in the tech industry. 1994: He transitioned to the computer reseller division of Intelligent Electronics as Vice President of Corporate Materials. 1997: Cook joined Apple Inc. as Senior Vice President for Worldwide Operations, playing a crucial role in streamlining the company's supply chain and manufacturing processes. 2005: He was promoted to Chief Operating Officer (COO) and continued to oversee Apple's global operations and sales. 2011: Following the temporary medical leave of Steve Jobs, Cook served as acting CEO, and later that year, he officially succeeded Jobs as CEO of Apple Inc.

data.name: Sundar Pichai
data.description: Sundar Pichai is the Chief Executive Officer (CEO) of Alphabet Inc., the parent company of Google. He is an Indian-American business executive and a prominent figure in the technology industry. Pichai is widely recognized for his leadership and contributions to Google's growth and development. He played a significant role in the development of various Google products, including Chrome, Chrome OS, and Android, which have become integral parts of the modern digital ecosystem. Pichai is known for his forward-thinking approach to innovation and his ability to steer the company towards continued success in a rapidly evolving technological landscape.
data.education: Indian Institute of Technology Kharagpur (IIT Kharagpur): Sundar Pichai earned his Bachelor of Technology (B.Tech) degree in Metallurgical Engineering from IIT Kharagpur in 1993. Stanford University: He furthered his education at Stanford University in the United States, where he earned a Master of Science (M.S.) degree in Materials Science and Engineering. Wharton School of the University of Pennsylvania: Pichai also holds an MBA from the Wharton School of the University of Pennsylvania
data.career_path: 2004: Sundar Pichai joined Google as a product management executive, leading efforts on the development of Google's popular web browser, Chrome. 2012: He became Senior Vice President of Chrome and Apps, overseeing the growth of the Chrome browser and Chrome OS. 2013: Pichai took on additional responsibilities and became the head of Android, Google's mobile operating system, which became the world's most widely used mobile platform under his leadership. 2015: Sundar Pichai was appointed CEO of Google Inc., succeeding Larry Page, and he continued to hold this position even after Google restructured and became a subsidiary of Alphabet Inc., where he also became the CEO of Alphabet.

data.name: Mukesh Ambani
data.description: Mukesh Ambani is an Indian businessman and the chairman and largest shareholder of Reliance Industries Limited (RIL), a conglomerate with interests in petrochemicals, refining, oil, and telecommunications. Born on April 19, 1957, in Yemen, he is the son of the late Dhirubhai Ambani, the founder of RIL. Mukesh Ambani is known for his visionary leadership and significant contributions to the growth of RIL, transforming it into one of India's largest and most valuable companies. He is also recognized for his role in revolutionizing the Indian telecommunications industry through the launch of Jio, a digital network that brought affordable internet access to millions of people.
data.education: Bachelor of Chemical Engineering from the Institute of Chemical Technology (formerly UDCT), Mumbai, India - Graduated in 1979
data.career_path: 1981: Mukesh Ambani joined Reliance Industries and led the construction of a polyester filament yarn plant.1983: He spearheaded the backward integration project for Reliance, establishing the world's largest grassroots refinery in Jamnagar, Gujarat.2002: Under his leadership, Reliance entered the petrochemicals sector with the commissioning of the largest integrated petrochemical complex in the world.2016: Mukesh Ambani launched Reliance Jio, a revolutionary telecommunications network that disrupted the industry by offering affordable data and free voice calls.Beyond his business roles, he has been involved in various philanthropic and social initiatives, contributing to healthcare, education, and rural development

data.name: Larry Ellison
data.description: Larry Ellison is a renowned American entrepreneur best known as the co-founder and former CEO of Oracle Corporation, one of the world's largest and most influential software and technology companies. With a dynamic and visionary leadership style, Ellison played a pivotal role in shaping the modern database industry. His relentless drive for innovation and business acumen led Oracle to develop groundbreaking technologies that have transformed the way businesses manage and process data.
data.education: Larry Ellison attended the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign from 1962 to 1964. He later transferred to the University of Chicago but dropped out after a single semester in 1966. Ellison's education was interrupted due to his mother's illness and subsequent passing.
data.career_path: 1977: Ellison co-founded Software Development Laboratories (SDL) with two partners and developed the first commercially successful relational database management system (RDBMS) called Oracle.1982: The company's name was changed to Oracle Systems Corporation, and its flagship product became Oracle Database.1997: Oracle became one of the world's largest software companies under Ellison's leadership.2014: Ellison stepped down from his CEO role, becoming Oracle's Executive Chairman and Chief Technology Officer.2016: He relinquished the CEO position but remained as Chairman and Chief Technology Officer.2020: Larry Ellison became the Chairman and Chief Technology Officer of Oracle's board.2021: Ellison's net worth made him one of the wealthiest individuals globally, with a significant focus on investments in technology and real estate.

data.name: Bernard Arnault
data.description: Bernard Arnault is a prominent French businessman and one of the world's wealthiest individuals. He is best known as the Chairman and CEO of LVMH Moët Hennessy Louis Vuitton, a multinational luxury goods conglomerate. Arnault has played a pivotal role in transforming LVMH into a global luxury powerhouse, overseeing an impressive portfolio of brands spanning fashion, cosmetics, jewelry, and more. His business acumen and strategic leadership have solidified his reputation as a key figure in the luxury industry.
data.education: 1971: Bernard Arnault graduated from the Ecole Polytechnique with a degree in Engineering.1974: He earned a Master's degree in Business Administration from the prestigious École des Hautes Études Commerciales (HEC) in Paris.
data.career_path: 1971-1978: Arnault initially worked for his father's construction company, Ferret-Savinel.1984: He became the majority shareholder of Financière Agache, a holding company.1987: Arnault orchestrated the merger of Financière Agache with Moët Hennessy, creating LVMH.1990s-2000s: Under Arnault's leadership, LVMH expanded its luxury brand portfolio through acquisitions, including brands like Christian Dior, Givenchy, and Sephora.2017: LVMH acquired Christian Dior Couture, further consolidating its presence in the luxury fashion sector.2021: Arnault briefly became the world's richest person, surpassing Jeff Bezos, before fluctuating stock prices.

data.name: Richard Branson
data.description: Richard Branson is a British entrepreneur and business magnate known for his diverse ventures in the business world. He is the founder of the Virgin Group, a conglomerate that encompasses a wide range of industries, including music, airlines, telecommunications, and space travel. Branson is renowned for his innovative and adventurous spirit, often pushing boundaries and challenging the status quo. He has a reputation for his charismatic personality and risk-taking approach to business, making him one of the most recognizable and influential figures in the global business landscape.
data.education: Stowe School (Buckinghamshire, England): Branson attended Stowe School, an independent boarding school, until the age of 16. However, his struggles with dyslexia led him to perform poorly academically.Educational struggles: Due to his dyslexia, Branson faced challenges in traditional education and subsequently left school at 16 without pursuing higher education.
data.career_path: 1970: Branson founded the Virgin Group, starting with a mail-order record business.1972: Virgin Records signed its first recording artist, Mike Oldfield, and released the iconic album "Tubular Bells."1984: The launch of Virgin Atlantic Airways, a milestone in Branson's business journey, marked his entry into the airline industry.1999: Virgin Mobile was introduced, initiating Branson's involvement in the telecommunications sector.2004: Branson founded Virgin Galactic, a spaceflight company with the goal of offering commercial space travel experiences.2006: Virgin Trains expanded Branson's business interests into the railway sector.2018: The formation of Virgin Hyperloop, a transportation technology company focused on high-speed pod-based travel systems.

data.name: Michael Bloomberg
data.description: Michael Bloomberg is an American entrepreneur, philanthropist, and former politician. He is best known as the co-founder, CEO, and majority owner of Bloomberg L.P., a global financial services, software, and media company. Bloomberg served as the 108th Mayor of New York City from 2002 to 2013, during which he focused on various urban development initiatives, public health campaigns, and environmental policies. He is recognized for his significant contributions to business, politics, and philanthropy.
data.education: 1960: Graduated from Medford High School in Medford, Massachusetts.1964: Earned a Bachelor of Science degree in Electrical Engineering from Johns Hopkins University.1966: Obtained a Master of Business Administration (MBA) degree from Harvard Business School.
data.career_path: 1966-1981: Bloomberg began his career at Salomon Brothers, a Wall Street investment bank, where he rose through the ranks to become a general partner.1981: He was let go from Salomon Brothers due to the company's acquisition, resulting in the founding of Innovative Market Systems (IMS), which later became Bloomberg L.P. The company revolutionized financial data analytics and technology.2002-2013: Bloomberg was elected the Mayor of New York City, serving three terms. During his tenure, he implemented various policies to improve public health, education, and environmental sustainability.2014-present: After leaving the mayor's office, Bloomberg returned to lead Bloomberg L.P. and remained active in philanthropy, focusing on issues like climate change, gun control, and public health through his charitable foundation, Bloomberg Philanthropies.

data.name: Martin Luther King Jr.
data.description: Martin Luther King Jr. was a prominent American civil rights activist and leader known for his pivotal role in the advancement of civil rights and equality for African Americans in the United States. He is most famous for his advocacy of nonviolent protest methods to combat racial segregation and discrimination. Through his charismatic leadership, inspiring speeches, and commitment to justice, he became an iconic figure in the fight for civil rights and social change.
data.education: Bachelor of Arts in Sociology from Morehouse College (1948)Bachelor of Divinity from Crozer Theological Seminary (1951)Doctor of Philosophy in Systematic Theology from Boston University (1955)
data.career_path: Ordained as a Baptist minister (1948)Led the Montgomery bus boycott after Rosa Parks' arrest (1955-1956)Co-founded the Southern Christian Leadership Conference (SCLC) (1957)Delivered his famous "I Have a Dream" speech during the March on Washington for Jobs and Freedom (1963)Advocated for voting rights during the Selma to Montgomery marches (1965)Assassinated in Memphis, Tennessee (1968), leaving a lasting legacy in the civil rights movement and beyond.

data.name: Rosa Parks
data.description: Rosa Parks was a prominent African American civil rights activist known for her pivotal role in the Montgomery Bus Boycott, a significant event in the U.S. civil rights movement. Born on February 4, 1913, in Tuskegee, Alabama, she became an emblem of resistance against racial segregation. Her refusal to give up her bus seat to a white passenger in Montgomery, Alabama, on December 1, 1955, sparked a year-long boycott of the city's bus system by African Americans, ultimately leading to the desegregation of buses. Rosa Parks' courageous act inspired a nationwide movement for equal rights and justice.
data.education: Rosa Parks attended segregated schools in Alabama throughout her childhood. Her formal education included completing her high school diploma at the Montgomery Industrial School for Girls in 1929.
data.career_path: 1930s-1940s: Rosa Parks began her career as a seamstress in Montgomery, Alabama.1943: She joined the local chapter of the NAACP (National Association for the Advancement of Colored People) and became involved in civil rights activism.1955: Rosa Parks' refusal to give up her bus seat ignited the Montgomery Bus Boycott.Late 1950s-1960s: After the success of the boycott, Parks and her husband faced ongoing harassment and struggled to find work in Montgomery. They eventually moved to Detroit, Michigan.1965: Rosa Parks took a job in the office of U.S. Representative John Conyers, where she worked until her retirement in 1988. During this time, she continued to advocate for civil rights and social justice.1999: Rosa Parks was awarded the Congressional Gold Medal, the highest honor a civilian can receive in the United States.Rosa Parks passed away on October 24, 2005, leaving behind a legacy of courage and a lasting impact on the civil rights movement.

data.name: Mother Teresa
data.description: Mother Teresa was a renowned Albanian-Indian nun and missionary, known for her unwavering dedication to serving the poor and sick. Born Agnes Gonxha Bojaxhiu on August 26, 1910, in Skopje, which is now part of North Macedonia, she joined the Sisters of Loreto at the age of 18 and later took the name Sister Mary Teresa. After a period of training in Ireland, she arrived in India in 1929. Her career path took a significant turn in 1946 when she received a "call within a call" to leave her convent and devote herself to the impoverished and ailing in the slums of Calcutta. She founded the Missionaries of Charity in 1950, an organization dedicated to providing aid to those in need, and her selfless work earned her global recognition. Mother Teresa received the Nobel Peace Prize in 1979 and continued her humanitarian efforts until her passing on September 5, 1997.
data.education: 1928: Arrived in Ireland to join the Sisters of Loreto in Dublin1929: Traveled to Darjeeling, India, for her novitiate and took her first religious vows
data.career_path: 1931-1948: Taught at St. Mary's High School in Calcutta, India1948: Received a "call within a call" to serve the poor and started her humanitarian work1950: Founded the Missionaries of Charity, focused on aiding the destitute and dying1979: Awarded the Nobel Peace Prize for her dedicated efforts to alleviate human sufferingContinued to expand her charitable work globally until her passing in 1997

data.name: Pablo Picasso
data.description: Pablo Picasso, a Spanish painter, sculptor, and one of the most influential artists of the 20th century, is renowned for co-founding the Cubist movement and his prolific output across various artistic mediums. His innovative approach to art and his ability to constantly evolve his style set him apart as a creative visionary. Picasso's work not only transformed the art world but also left an indelible mark on the way people perceive and engage with visual expression.
data.education: 1895: Enrolled in the School of Fine Arts in Barcelona at the age of 13.1897: Enrolled at the Royal Academy of San Fernando in Madrid, Spain.
data.career_path: 1890s: Picasso's artistic talent emerged early, as he produced his first major painting, "The First Communion," at the age of 15.1900s: He transitioned through various artistic phases, including the Blue Period and the Rose Period, before co-founding the Cubist movement with Georges Braque around 1907–1909.1910s: Picasso continued to experiment with different styles and mediums, collaborating with other artists and delving into sculpture. His art remained highly influential during the tumultuous World War I years.1920s–1930s: His work evolved further, incorporating Surrealist elements and often exploring complex themes. He also produced politically charged pieces in response to the Spanish Civil War.1940s–1950s: Picasso's work took on new dimensions as he explored ceramics and lithography, and he was involved in both personal and professional collaborations.1960s: He created a prolific amount of art during his later years, marked by a series of paintings centered around famous artworks from the past, reinterpreted in his unique style.Picasso's innovative spirit, immense creativity, and constant reinvention solidified his status as one of the 20th century's greatest artists. He passed away on April 8, 1973, leaving behind an enduring legacy that continues to shape modern art

data.name: Amelia Earhart
data.description: Amelia Earhart was a pioneering aviator and author, best known for being the first woman to fly solo across the Atlantic Ocean. Born on July 24, 1897, in Atchison, Kansas, she developed a fascination with aviation from an early age. Earhart's determination and groundbreaking achievements in the field of aviation made her an inspirational figure, challenging traditional gender roles and pushing the boundaries of what women could accomplish in a male-dominated industry. Tragically, she disappeared while attempting to circumnavigate the globe in 1937, sparking mystery and speculation that still captivates people's imagination to this day.
data.education: 1915-1916: Attended Ogontz School for Girls in Pennsylvania.1917-1919: Attended Columbia University studying medicine, but left to work as a nurse's aide during World War I.1920-1924: Attended Harvard University, taking courses in science and engineering.

Sadly, she vanished over the Pacific Ocean during this endeavor, and her fate remains a mystery.

data.name: Charlie Chaplin
data.description: Charlie Chaplin, born on April 16, 1889, in London, England, was a pioneering figure in the world of entertainment and cinema. He is renowned as one of the greatest silent film actors and comedians of all time. Chaplin's iconic character, "The Tramp," with his distinctive bowler hat, cane, and mustache, became a symbol of humor and resilience, transcending language barriers and cultural differences. His work often blended humor with social commentary, and he had a remarkable ability to connect with audiences on a deeply emotional level.
data.education: Charlie Chaplin's formal education was limited due to his challenging upbringing. He had minimal schooling, attending various institutions for brief periods during his childhood. His family's financial struggles and his early involvement in show business hindered his ability to pursue traditional education.
data.career_path: Chaplin's career path is marked by his gradual rise to stardom and lasting impact on the film industry:1900s-1910s: Chaplin began his career as a performer in music halls and vaudeville. He joined the Fred Karno comedy troupe, which took him to the United States in 1910. This marked his initial exposure to American audiences.1914: He signed with Keystone Studios, a significant moment in his career. During his time there, he developed his signature "Tramp" character and honed his comedic skills.1915-1917: Chaplin joined Essanay Studios and then Mutual Film Corporation, where he produced some of his most famous and critically acclaimed short films, including "The Tramp" (1915) and "The Immigrant" (1917).1919: He co-founded United Artists along with Mary Pickford, Douglas Fairbanks, and D.W. Griffith. This move gave him more creative control over his work and allowed him to experiment with longer feature films. 1920s-1930s: Chaplin continued to create memorable films such as "The Kid" (1921), "City Lights" (1931), and "Modern Times" (1936), which integrated social commentary into his comedy. His ability to transition from silent films to "talkies" was evident in "The Great Dictator" (1940), where he delivered his first spoken dialogue. 1950s-1970s: While his output decreased, Chaplin remained an influential figure. He directed and acted in films like "Limelight" (1952) and "A King in New York" (1957). However, his political views and personal controversies affected his popularity in the United States.

data.name: Anne Frank
data.description: Anne Frank was a Jewish girl who gained posthumous fame through her poignant and insightful diary, "The Diary of a Young Girl." Born on June 12, 1929, in Frankfurt, Germany, Anne and her family fled to Amsterdam to escape the Nazis. During World War II, they went into hiding in a concealed annex behind her father's business premises. Anne documented her thoughts, feelings, and experiences in her diary, providing an intimate and invaluable account of life in hiding. Tragically, the family was discovered in 1944, and Anne died in the Bergen-Belsen concentration camp in early 1945. Her diary was later published by her father, Otto Frank, becoming a globally recognized symbol of the Holocaust and the resilience of the human spirit.
data.education: Anne attended the Sixth Montessori School in Amsterdam until 1941, when she was forced to leave due to the anti-Jewish measures imposed by the Nazis.
data.career_path: Anne's life was tragically cut short by the Holocaust, and she didn't have the opportunity to pursue a traditional career path. However, her diary has had an enduring impact on literature, history, and human rights advocacy. Her words have served as a powerful testament to the horrors of the Holocaust and the importance of remembering and learning from history.

data.name: Malcolm X
data.description: Malcolm X was a prominent African-American civil rights activist and a vocal advocate for black empowerment and racial equality. Born on May 19, 1925, as Malcolm Little, he later adopted the surname "X" to symbolize his lost African heritage. Malcolm X's journey is marked by his transformation from a troubled youth involved in criminal activities to a passionate leader in the struggle against racial injustice. His powerful oratory skills and commitment to the principles of the Nation of Islam, an organization advocating for the rights of black Americans, made him a central figure in the civil rights movement of the 1960s. Malcolm X's beliefs evolved over time, and he eventually distanced himself from the Nation of Islam due to ideological differences. Tragically, he was assassinated on February 21, 1965, in New York City.
data.education: Malcolm X's formal education was disrupted by systemic racism, and he faced difficulties due to his skin color. He attended local schools in Lansing, Michigan, but his academic progress was hindered by racial bias. He dropped out of school at the age of 15 after a teacher discouraged his aspirations of becoming a lawyer. This event was a turning point, leading him down a troubled path.
data.career_path: Malcolm X's early life was marked by involvement in criminal activities, which eventually led to his incarceration in 1946. While in prison, he began educating himself extensively, devouring books and expanding his knowledge. He was particularly drawn to the teachings of Elijah Muhammad, the leader of the Nation of Islam. Upon his release in 1952, Malcolm X embraced the Nation's teachings and became a prominent minister and spokesperson for the organization. Throughout the 1950s and early 1960s, he gained recognition for his fiery speeches and advocacy for black separatism and self-sufficiency. However, his growing disillusionment with the Nation of Islam's leadership and teachings led to his departure from the organization in 1964. He embarked on a pilgrimage to Mecca, where he had a transformative experience that shifted his views on race and religion. Upon his return to the United States, he continued his activism, focusing on a more inclusive approach to civil rights and social justice. Tragically, Malcolm X's life was cut short when he was assassinated in 1965, leaving behind a complex legacy of activism and advocacy for racial equality.

data.name: Muhammad Ali
data.description: Muhammad Ali, born Cassius Marcellus Clay Jr. on January 17, 1942, was a legendary American boxer and cultural icon. Renowned for his extraordinary skills and charismatic personality, Ali is widely considered one of the greatest heavyweight boxers in history. He was not only known for his prowess in the boxing ring but also for his strong social and political stands. Ali's refusal to be drafted into the Vietnam War due to his religious beliefs and opposition to the war effort made him a symbol of resistance and conviction. He became the first three-time heavyweight champion of the world, achieving this feat in 1964, 1974, and 1978. His famous fights against Sonny Liston, Joe Frazier, and George Foreman, among others, are etched in the annals of sports history. Beyond his boxing accomplishments, Ali's larger-than-life personality and activism left an indelible mark on the world.
data.education: Muhammad Ali attended Central High School in Louisville, Kentucky. He graduated in 1960.

data.name: Billie Jean King
data.description: Billie Jean King is a renowned American tennis player who made an indelible mark on the sport and society at large. Born on November 22, 1943, in Long Beach, California, she is celebrated not only for her remarkable tennis achievements but also for her pivotal role in advocating for gender equality in sports. King's dedication to breaking down barriers is perhaps best exemplified by her famous "Battle of the Sexes" match in 1973, where she defeated Bobby Riggs in a widely watched tennis spectacle that symbolized the empowerment of women in sports. Beyond her athletic prowess, King co-founded the Women's Tennis Association (WTA) and has been an instrumental figure in pushing for equal prize money and opportunities for female athletes. Her legacy extends far beyond the tennis court, as she continues to be a tireless advocate for social change and equality.
data.education: Billie Jean King attended Long Beach Polytechnic High School in Long Beach, California. After graduating from high school, she attended California State University, Los Angeles.

data.name: Malala Yousafzai
data.description: Malala Yousafzai is a Pakistani education activist known for her advocacy of girls' education and women's rights. She gained international recognition after surviving a targeted assassination attempt by the Taliban in 2012. Despite the attack, she continued to raise her voice for the right to education, becoming a symbol of resilience and courage. Malala co-authored the memoir "I Am Malala" and established the Malala Fund, an organization dedicated to promoting education for girls around the world. In 2014, she became the youngest recipient of the Nobel Peace Prize.

data.name: Greta Thunberg
data.description: Greta Thunberg is a Swedish environmental activist known for her passionate advocacy for global action against climate change. She gained international recognition for her "Fridays for Future" movement, which began as a solitary protest outside the Swedish parliament in 2018. Her unwavering commitment to raising awareness about the urgency of addressing climate change has inspired millions of young people around the world to participate in climate strikes and demand policy changes.
data.education: Greta Thunberg was born on January 3, 2003, in Stockholm, Sweden. She attended regular school until she was 15, at which point she decided to focus entirely on her climate activism. As a result, she stopped attending school and dedicated herself to raising awareness about the climate crisis and its implications.

Consequently, his educational pursuits were largely managed through private tutoring and home schooling to accommodate his demanding schedule.
